content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="6 H with a positive one charge, aqueous, plus 2 M n O 4 with a negative one charge, aqueous, plus 5 H 2 C 2 O 4, aqueous, reacts to produce, 10 C O 2, gas, plus 8 H 2 O, liquid, plus 2 M n with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>Mn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

A student dissolved a <math alttext="0.139 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.139</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of oxalic acid, <math alttext="H 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, in water in an Erlenmeyer flask. Then the student titrated the <math alttext="H 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution in the flask with a solution of <math alttext="K M n O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>KMnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which has a dark purple color. The balanced chemical equation for the reaction that occurred during the titration is shown above.

(a) Identify the species that was reduced in the titration reaction. Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="6 H with a positive one charge, aqueous, plus 2 M n O 4 with a negative one charge, aqueous, plus 5 H 2 C 2 O 4, aqueous, reacts to produce, 10 C O 2, gas, plus 8 H 2 O, liquid, plus 2 M n with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>Mn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

A student dissolved a <math alttext="0.139 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.139</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of oxalic acid, <math alttext="H 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, in water in an Erlenmeyer flask. Then the student titrated the <math alttext="H 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution in the flask with a solution of <math alttext="K M n O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>KMnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which has a dark purple color. The balanced chemical equation for the reaction that occurred during the titration is shown above.

(a) Identify the species that was reduced in the titration reaction. Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

(b) The student used a <math alttext="50.0 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buret to add the <math alttext="K M n O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>KMnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to the <math alttext="H 2 C 2 O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> until a faint lavender color was observed in the flask, an indication that the end point of the titration had been reached. The initial and final volume readings of the solution in the buret are shown below. Write down the initial reading and the final reading and use them to determine the volume of <math alttext="K M n O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>KMnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> that was added during the titration.

(c) Given that the concentration of <math alttext="K M n O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>KMnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="0.0235 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0235</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="M n O 4 with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mn</mtext><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions that completely reacted with the <math alttext="H 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The student proposes to perform another titration using a <math alttext="0.139 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.139</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="H 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, but this time using <math alttext="0.00143 molar K M n O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.00143</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>KMnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the buret. Would this titrant concentration be a reasonable choice to use if the student followed the same procedure and used the same equipment as before? Justify your response.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
